Banned

19 Jan 2021 - jacob

The terrible sting of being told to sit out of middle school class because I talked too much is an all too familiar feeling. Now, instead of roudy preteens like me, platforms and pop icons are the ones sent to the hallway. The recent wave of bans and deplatforms ranging from presidents to podcasts demonstrates a cultural shift years in the making.

This paradigm shift includes implicit assumptions with consequences that have not been realized. The main assumptions underlying this new era are: 1. platforms, left unregulated, are dangerous. 2. Effective management of irresponsible/damaging rhetoric is to erase and disappear it.

The power of the platform was born in the 2000s and cemented in the history of the world by the 2010s. The Arab Spring first demonstrated the power of platforms to unite and spread social change. United by the organizational and communication power of platforms, autocrats fell like dominoes. Later movements from Occupy Wallstreet to #BlackLivesMatter and #MeToo have proved effective at penetrating national discourse. Yet, not everything online is dedicated to such nobel causes.

Conspiracy theorists and manipulators have also found fertile ground for their work. From Q-Anon to election misinformation, the risks of platforms left unchecked became apparent. Faced with government inaction, platforms are expected to pick up the slack. Their responses from cigarette-like warning labels on posts to banning users represent an acknowledgement of the danger posed by “misused” platforms.

I find no issue with this assumption of the risk of platforms, notwithstanding the consequences of this premise.

the restriction of ideas and speech will only push it into the “underground”

there must be a broader societal dialogue about how we would like to see these# powerful platforms used.
